title: How many countries will experience 10 or more cases of poliovirus in 2017?
preds: This month more cases found in Pakistan in last 2 weeks.

Working as displayed here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/650886 If the most recent GPEI update, the final one before the question's closing date, is being used to adjudicate, the forecast shoulder be 0% for "4 countries". If the recent run of three cases are coincidental, and the question is not being adjudicated until the end of January (to wait for cases with onset of paralysis in December to be reported), then the forecast should be only 1% for "4 countries". If the cases are _not_ coincidental, and the question is not being adjudicated for another 4 weeks, then we need to make some assumptions about how likely it is for a case to show up each week. If we assume a 1 in 2 chance of a case each week, there will be an additional 2 (or more) cases 11 times in 16 (69%).  Thus this should be our forecast for "4 countries".
If we assume a 1 in 3 chance of a case each week, there will be an additional 2+ cases 11 times in 81 (14%).
If we assume a 1 in 4 chance of a case each week, there will be an additional 2+ cases 11 times in 256 (4%).
If we assume a 1 in 5 chance of a case each week, there will be an additional 2+ cases 11 times in 625 (2%).
And a 1 in 6 chance of a case each week is out "co-incidence" level, based upon frequency of cases throughout 2017 as a whole, which gives 1% as described above. I'm willing to increase the probability from the baseline 1 in 6 (17%) chance of a case each week to a 1 in 4 (25%) chance.

http://www.endpolio.com.pk/polioin-pakistan/polio-cases-district-wise-2017 I thought this question was effectively settled, but three cases in quick succession in Pakistan (onset of paralysis on 9,13 and 15 November) are ominous. Assuming a criterion for resolution is the date of paralysis onset, we have more than a month to go, and I'd rather be cautious - especially as I'm unlikely to be able to do any further forecasting before New Year's Eve because of travel.

The corruption of governments and medical organizations is so complete that even as awareness of vaccine induced infection is spreading the ability of poor people to assert medical freedom is not enough to effectively resist forced or coerced vaccination.

Thanks to @JMR2017 for flagging the GPEI udate. Pakistan now up to 8 cases, with 2-3 weeks to go - seems to be making a late dash for the finish line. Chance of a new case in Pakistan is about 1 in 6 each week (but much higher if only considering the last couple of months), so chance of 2 cases in next 2 weeks is roughly 1 in 6^2, or roughly 1 in 36.    Hmm ... this question ain't over yet ...
Pakistan will be at 8 cases by next week as advance reporting of a new case was published.

Whoa!  Wait a minute! @Khalid, @Gibson, @cdob63 I'd been ignoring this question for a bit, having pushed to 100% for "3". However, Pakistan now up to 7 cases, with 2-3 weeks to go.  Chance of a new case in Pakistan is about 1 in 7 each week, so chance of 3 cases in next 3 weeks is roughly 1 in 7^3, or roughly 1 in 350.  I'm happy to open the door again, very slightly, on the possibility of a "4".

Would have gone to 100% for "3" if not for the 6th case per @Khalid.   _Very_ roughly, 1 in 8 chances of a case in Pakistan each week through this year.  So 1 in 8^4 gives us the chance of 1 case in each of the 4 remaining weeks, or 1 in 4000.  Of course, cases tend to run in clusters, and the probabilities each week are not independent, so round it up to 1 in 100.

Affirming 99% for 3 countries. Another four cases before this question closes is highly unlikely. https://www.dawn.com/news/1374769/karachi-reports-second-polio-case-in-three-months "KARACHI: A second polio case within three months has emerged in the city, this time in a five-month-old baby, setting off alarm bells and exposing the fact that authorities in the metropolis have yet to eradicate the crippling disease, officials said on Tuesday. “The second case, too, involves an Afghan family. A five-month-old boy has fallen prey to the virus in UC-4 of Gadap,” said a senior official in the Sindh health ministry. Officials said the child had duly been administered with anti-polio drops during frequent campaigns. However, they blamed “low immunity” in the child’s body because of malnutrition that failed to save him. “He had received polio drops, but no routine immunisation,” said a senior official. Officials at the Emergency Operation Centre (EOC) for Polio in Sindh identified the boy as Zaibullah, son of Ghulam Sakhi, a resident of UC-4 Gadap. “The child has contracted the virus affecting both of his legs. The family hails from Afghanistan.” This case also involves an Afghan family More than three months ago the city produced its first case after remaining safe from the crippling disease for 20 months. The seven-year-old victim, too, belonged to an Afghan family whose parents refused to inoculate him against polio. It was also the first case reported in Sindh since October last year."
Going 100% to three due to the caseload in three countries and the fact that Pakistan is nowhere close to 10 cases.
Time running out for Pakistan to become the 4th nation.
Stepping down my boxes due to not reading deeper in to the data.  So Pakistan isn't one. Only 3. It needs another 5 cases.

Did I miss something? It's in 4 countries already, and Nigeria has 8 of one type and just need 2 more cases to become the 5th country. Why are there strong votes for 3 countries? Is it 10 combined of both types or 10 each? Wild and vaccine?

Hello, I'm entering for the last 60 days, mainly because it's one of the two dozen unresolved geopolitical questions without a clear decision; while squarely fitting my current private interest in immunology. For prevalence data, I heavily rely on @Khalid's outstanding and highly, highly committed tracking of the last two years. There seems to be seasonality to the spread of poliomyelitis, as indicated by the CDC:  “[19th century] epidemics of polio were reported from developed countries in the Northern Hemisphere each summer and fall.“ [1] I suspect a mother's drinking, dust, lack of rain might play a role in summer to enter a child's throat for transmissions other than oral vaccination. "Poliovirus infection typically peaks in the summer months in temperate climates. There is no seasonal pattern in tropical climates." [1] The lack of seasonality in wet tropical places suggests the importance of dust in the fecal-mouth transmission outside the vaccination route. Once infected, a person remains infectious for 6 weeks; "For the onset of paralysis in paralytic poliomyelitis, the incubation period usually is 7 to 21 days."[1] Hence, a one-child unsymptomatic or mild infection might yield a paralysis in other children 60 days later. The current risk is  • one in 2.5 million oral vaccine intakes, or roughly 
• one event in a million newborn-years, because a newborn will have one to three doses in the first 18 months. Moreover, the risk is  • seven in a million vaccinated adult-years (seven for orally vaccinated vs. zero for inactivated polio vaccines). Moreover, the risk is  • 50,000 in a million immunodeficient adult-years.[1] By deduction, the October-vaccination campaign in the DRC with 10 million units (see @chwang http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/598271) yields another 5 cases; the question is whether the onset reports will come in before New Years Eve. A big hinderance to the “body count” are the operative side of the medical infrastructure. I guess there are more lame children than actually found and reported. Turning to some other things, I speculate about the following countries (ISO codes): • SYR, Damascus – yes
• AFG, Kabul — yes
• PAK, Islamabad — no
• COD, Kinshasa — yes
• NGA, Abuja — no [1] https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/polio.html

In 1988 — when wild poliovirus was in more than 125 countries, paralyzing 350,000 people every year — the World Health Assembly launched the Global Polio Eradication Initiative to help eliminate the disease through a mass immunization campaign.
In 2007 the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation joined other major health organizations already committed to the GPEI, contributing nearly $3 billion toward eradicating polio by 2019.
Today 12 cases of poliovirus exist in two countries, and the Gates Foundation is optimistic polio could be completely wiped out this year.

Slightly upgrading chances of 2 countries with 10+ cases. Congo is most likely due to 9 cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV). Congo is planning to start its next childhood immunization push (10 million units) starting at the end of October, which may paradoxically increase the odds of one more cVDPV case by the end of 2017.  I believe it will be unlikely that 3 more cases of WPV will be detected in Afghanistan in the next 2.5 months. http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/

Just noticed the October Update 18 for Afghanistan: 
"A response vaccination campaign is currently being implemented for the new polio case, targeting about 150,000 children in five districts of the eastern region. The next sub-national immunization days are planned during the first half of November 2017."

As of October 18, Afghanistan is now at 7 cases, closing on where it was last year YTD. DRC is still at 9. So 1 country is certain (Syria), 2 is highly probable, and 3 countries is becoming increasingly possible.  74 days remaining in the calendar year...

Thanks for the nice pickup @Khalid.  Afghanistan now at 70% of target with 79% of year so far gone.  From an alternative perspective, at this time last year, Afghanistan was only at 62% of its eventual end-of-year total.  So I agree, "touch and go" indeed! I do wonder about a photo finish scenario.  The GPEI weekly reports are dated each Wednesday, so the final report of the 2017 year will be dated 27th Dec, but probably be released some time on the 29th.  What if a 10th case is found in Afghanistan on the 31st of December?  This would not appear in a GPEI weekly report until the report dated 3rd Jan is published on 5th Jan.   I am assuming that GJO _would_ count a case in that situation.  After all, the country would "experience 10 or more cases of poliovirus in 2017", and the cases would be "reported by the GPEI", albeit the report itself might not occur during the 2017 calendar year. Nonetheless, for the moment ...
INCREASE probability that Afghanistan will reach 10 cases: 0.40 -> 0.45

DRC remains at 9, Pakistan at 5 but Afghanistan will increase from 6 to 7 in the next update.
Probability of one more in the DRC in the next ten weeks remains very high while that of Pakistan reporting five more in the same period is decreasing. Afghanistan remains touch and go, with 7 by 15 September. However, reflecting the passage of time, I'm reducing the probability of 4 countries from 10 to 5, reducing the probability of 3 countries from 55 to 50, increasing that of two countries to 40, and increasing that of one (just Syria) from 0 to 5%.

I'd welcome corrections from ppl who (unlike me) understand statistics... i don't really know what i'm doing, but the calculations seemed fun to try and make a mess of: (Note1: I'm assuming a very low (perhaps too low) probability that either Pakistan or Afghanistan reaches 10 cases and a negligible probability of sufficient polio cases in countries that are not Syria/Congo/Afghanistan/Pakistan.)  (Note2: According to the polio eradication website by which this question is measured, Congo has a vaccination effort scheduled for the end of October that should reach 10 million children. I figure this could mean an additional probability of detection during that timeframe; but on the other hand,  a similar push in Pakistan that was to reach ~38 million children (if memory serves) only coincided with the reporting of a single additional case in Pakistan... this is a very, very, very rare disease.[edit2:/] @Khalid points out there is a lag between detection and reporting, so I may not have waited long enough in drawing this conclusion; that said, I'm still not aware of any additional forthcoming cases detected during the course of Pakistan's vaccination effort.[/edit]) Congo would only require one more instance of detection to reach 10 cases. Using the timeframe of this question as a base rate, there is currently a (4weeks_in_which_an_instance_of_detection_in_congo_occurred /13-weeks_elapsed) = ~31% probability of Congo reporting at least one case in a given week (if I counted right). I don't really know what I'm doing, but (if I'm thinking about it the right way) the plan is to use that weekly probability to adjust the "1" bucket each week that Congo goes without reporting a case by readjusting the number of weeks elapsed in the calculation above and the number of weeks on which to perform a trial remaining using the BINOMDIST function in excel, which returns the probability of x or fewer successes in
n independent Bernoulli trials: BINOMDIST(x, n,p, cumulative=TRUE), where x=0, n is the number of remaining weeks in the question, p = 4/(total number of weeks elapsed in the question) (I think cumulative is irrelevant because x=0). The math when applied to such assumptions says Congo should report a case soon (obviating all this elaborate calculation), but if it doesn't, subsequent weeks for the 1-bucket would look something like this: 10/17/17	: 2%
10/24/17	: 3%
10/31/17	: 6%
11/7/17	: 10%
11/14/17	: 15%
11/21/17	: 22%
11/28/17	: 31%
12/5/17	: 41%
12/12/17	: 53%
12/19/17	: 67%
12/26/17	: 83% edit1: something should i guess be added back for the possibilities that one of either afghanistan or pakistan but not congo reaches 10 cases, but i haven't done that calculation; could be fun but probably negligible given the above assumptions... i'll just fudge for now. [edits 3&4:/] might be better to assume 4-9 instances of detection and daily (rather than weekly) Bernouli trials (i.e., 4-to-9-detections/(7days/week*13weeks), the range in the numerator following from the fact that each instance of detection could have multiple cases or just one). in the event time passes without detection, i'd probably weight recent (non-)events more, which could result in dropping one or more earlier instances of detection from the model, resulting in higher probabilities for the "1" bucket. [/edit] [edit 2017-11-18] this was super-wrong; for most of this question, I failed to appreciate how confirmation of cases lags ***reported*** detection. even then, I don't think I'd've been in the right buckets (incorrectly weighting seasonality), but I should've been much closer... ugh.

Based on the new case in Afghanistan.

Syria has already met the criteria. Of the remaining countries on the GPEI site, only Afghanistan and the Congo appear close. Afghanistan has had 5 cases of wild-type polio; more communicable but there is a nationwide polio vaccine push slated for August. The Congo currently has 7 cases, all vaccine-derived. There has not been any reports of wild type polio there. Experts do not expect additional reports of vaccine-derived polio cases there. http://applications.emro.who.int/docs/AFG/COPub_AFG_2017_19923_EN.pdf?ua=1
http://polioeradication.org/where-we-work/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/

1) Syria already has more than 10 cases reported.  
Assume 100% chance for Syria. 2) Afghanistan is ahead of roughly on track to have same number as last year, 13.
Assume 80% chance for Afghanistan. 3) Pakistan is behind schedule.
Assume 30% chance for Pakistan. Given these probabilities, expected value of
62% chance for 1, 24% chance for 2, 14% chance for 3.

Poliovirus in today's world is a result of war and poverty.  Syria has already crossed the threshold of 10 with a current count of 27 total cases.  Syria has been a worn torn country for the past six years and vaccination shortages should be expected.  The DRC and Afghanistan have a respective 4 and 5 cases more than halfway through the year.  It seems likely either the DRC or Afghanistan will cross the threshold of 10 cases by the end of the year.

http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/ From 01 Jan to date (24 July), there have been 8 Wild Type 1 (WPV) and 31 Circulating Vaccine-Derived (cVDPV) polio virus cases reported, compared to 20 WPV and 4 cVDPV at the same time last year. There has been a reduction in WPV in Pakistan (3 cases so far this year compared to 13 last year), Nigeria (none compared to 4) and Afghanistan (5 compared to 6), but the increase in cVDPV is disturbing, as it has been caused by the Type 2 component of the oral vaccine, even though Type 2 has not occurred in the wild since 1999. However, since April 2016  oral tri-valent vaccine has been replaced by the bivalent type (Types 1 and 3 only), so we may see less of cVDPV Type 2 from now on. In 2016 only Pakistan and Afghanistan reported more than 10 cases, whereas this year Syria already has more. There is some concern about more cases being found in the Democratic Republic of the Congo due to civil war like conditions in parts of the country, and my personal choice of a wild card is Yemen where  children are unlikely to have been immunized over the last year or two (and where a major cholera epidemic is currently raging). Pro-rata compared to 2016, Afghanistan is on track to have 11 cases in 2017, Pakistan 5.  There are common "corridors" between the two countries where immunization campaigns are unable to reach the entire population so there remains a  risk of a spurt in reported cases, even though a major effort spanning both countries is currently under way to reach the remotest areas and reluctant families. On balance, the most likely outcome appears to be that two countries will exceed ten cases, with Afghanistan being the second country after Syria. However, Pakistan can't be ruled out, while the Congo (and Yemen) may also be at risk.
Now that health workers are stepping up surveillance it is possible that more than three will occur but most likely in 2018.

I gave Afghanistan a 45% chance, Pakistan a 15% chance after eyeballing http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/, and ignored all other countries. I also didn't make any adjustments for correlations between polio outbreaks.

In 2016, 2 countries had more than 10 cases (Afghanistan - 13 and Pakistan - 21).  By July, 2017, only the Syrian Arab Republic has more than 10 cases, three countries have more than 1 (Democratic Republic Of The Congo and Afghanistan), but Nigeria that had cases in 2016 responded well to the strains affecting the country in 2016.  In my prediction, I included the chance for Afghanistan  and Pakistan to have more than 10 cases too.

I looked at the data and came to the conclusion that in addition to Syria already exceeding 10, Afghanistan and DRC could also get there. I think @Danbell sums it all up very well and I'm going with his prediction for now. I also looked at the Global Peace Index as war and terrorism contributes to this problem. Was looking at countries that worsened in the 2017 index and Syria remains the worst/least peaceful country in the world with Afghanistan second.
Syria and Afghanistan added cases this week as of 7/19:
Summary of newly-reported viruses this week:  Afghanistan – one new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) isolated from an acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) case and one new WPV1-positive environmental sample; Syria – four new circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) isolated from AFP cases.

Compared to a lot of questions I answer here, this was actually a nice one to look into because of how good the progress has been in the last few years. So far this year 10 of more cases have only been reported in Syria. Lookinng at the trend lines, there were two countries in 2016, three countries in 2015 & 2014, and 6 countries in 2013. Point in this disease is steadily retreating and the fact that no new cases have been reported since mid June. Pakistan's numbers are way down from previous years and I don't see polio exploding (relatively speaking) there in the next few months. That said, one new case per month in either Afghanistan or the DR Congo seems reasonable.
As per Khalid reasoning. I do think Polio will be eradicated this decade but not until the fighting in Syria/Afghanistan ends.

http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/ As per the latest report, so far this year there have been 27 cases reported in Syria, 5 in Afghanistan and 3 in Pakistan.  At the same rate for the second half of this year, Afghanistan may just hit 10.  This question will be like the Ebola one from last year, requiring regular checking of the weekly updates.

Based on the Global Polio Eradication Initiative's (GPEI) data, Syria already exceeds the 10 case minimum with 27 cases of cVDPD (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/). Afghanistan is on pace to match last year's total of 13 cases given YTD data, and as an endemic country is always a candidate to exceed 10 cases. Pakistan is reporting significantly less cases based on YTD data compared to last year at this point, but is an endemic country, so the potential exists for a large outbreak to push it over the 10 case bar. However, current focus on eradicating polio in the country decreases the likelihood of a large outbreak not previously reported. Focusing primarily on 2 countries at this point. DRC could come into contention, given that it also has an Ebola outbreak to contend with straining medical resources, and the Lake Chad countries could come into play with a spread from DRC and conflict in CAR. But there are no strong indicators of a potential large outbreak at the moment.
